review_title: Overall positive experience with a few negatives
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Good work-life balance, leadership from senior management, and organizational culture. Food Bankers are kind, hard-working, and don’t loose sight of our mission.
cons: Some team leaders can be extremely disorganized and lack thoroughness, resulting on a team working inefficiently, stressed, and making mistakes that are unacceptable for an organization of its caliber.

review_title: Growth potential in non trusting environment
pros: Work / life balance with good benefits/ holidays. Purposeful Mission
cons: Non trusting management. Back stabbing, two faced managers who pretend to care about you. Management Gossip Very little successful communication

pros: Friendly, slow pace, kind, everyone wants to be there

job_title: Tax Preparer in New York, NY
pros: when I didn't know something I was able to easily get help and guided through the software they used which was tax slayer.
cons: I was hoping for a full-time position but they didn't have.

pros: Everyone is friendly with each other.
cons: The location is a bit hard to travel to.

pros:
They provided trainings and helpful resources for you to become a certified volunteer so you dont have to stress out. Volunteer schedules were pretty flexible. Learned a lot of things related to tax filing, great opportunity to make contributions to your community especially for low-to-moderate income family. 
Staff and coordinators were nice and willful to answer any questions you may have. Workload was depend on how fast and accurate you complete a case, they will definitely not make you feel too much pressure.
cons: Pretty much none, but do expect that you might experience some technical issues from their ends and need time to fix, that could be a little bit annoying when there's nothing can help about it.

pros: Definitely basic knowledge of income tax gained
cons: Some sites are too far

review_title: A great place to learn & grow
pros: I hope the rewarding nature of the work goes without saying, so I'll address the culture, which is one of the most important determinants of a thriving (or toxic) workplace. The leadership here, from Directors on up to C-Suite, challenges everyone to grow in their roles and actively makes opportunities for growth available. And I'm not just referring to professional development courses or conferences, I mean they seek to deliberately give you opportunities to grow within your role by taking chances, testing ideas, and thinking outside of the box without fear of failure or reprisal - it's truly gratifying! The teams are like families, which is not easy to achieve in a fully remote environment, so that's a big kudos to the HR squad for hiring people who "fit" each other well and embody the values. Speaking for myself, I feel the ease to bring my authentic self to work every single day, respectfully speak my mind, openly share my expertise, and protectively manage expectations with EVERYONE, no matter their title or tenure, and I'm received with kindness, eagerness, and (dare I say it) appreciation. I think everyone on my team will say the same. For me, that's priceless. If you're motivated by doing good work, being challenged to excel, being expected to solve a problem instead of complain about it (but there's always an open ear nearby if you need to vent lol), and being positioned to fail UP on your own merits - with lots and lots of support to buttress you in your ascent - then I highly encourage you to apply here, we're waiting for you ;-)
cons: Not a con, but I want to be transparent. A lot of the organization is new. Much of leadership. Our core values. Our org structure. Our staff. This means there are certainly knowledge gaps, it's not uncommon to ask at least once a week "who do I go to learn more about X?" lol. I'm fine with that, we're all finding our footing together. I believe leadership is committed to getting all of this buttoned up, but it's gonna take time. If you're a self starter, and ok with a bit of uncertainty as the details are hammered out, this will not deter you. But if you prefer a more established structure, you may want to wait another 6-12 months before applying. The org is growing quickly, but the uncertainty of when and how we'll get it all buttoned up may not be welcome to some. I personally find it exciting, and think it gives a chance for the entire body of staff to have an active role in "building" the org we become.

pros: Great hours, great team, and feeling of giving back
cons: You may not get the office location you want when starting.

pros: Many dedicated employees genuinely want to do the right thing.
cons: Worst leadership on the planet.

pros: High workload from the pandemic. High impact organization growing in exciting ways. Great place to be to help make a difference.
cons: Really a pro - always something to do so never a dull moment.

pros: Salary is good and benefits
cons: Nothing that i can mention

pros: Great culture, open to new ideas and everyone is aligned on mission
cons: We are a lean team- so be ready to roll up you sleeves. Not really a con but something applicants need to know.

pros: Great mission. They help many people in need.
cons: Lots of turnover. Growth opportunities are limited.

pros: Days are full / lots of work. a lot of changes happening to make a stronger organization.
cons: 3 office locations so not everyone is together

pros: Some of the smartest, most hardworking people in the industry
cons: At times, could be a harsh environment

pros: Meaningful work supporting vulnerable New Yorkers.
cons: Some challenging employees and expectations.

pros: You can't beat the mission. The work Food Bank does is far reaching and incredibly important to the New Yorkers who rely on their services. Many staff members are wholeheartedly committed to the work.
cons: It varies slightly by department, but the work culture is abysmal. Turnover is out of control, very few people with talent stay for long. Employees either coast under the radar or work themselves into the ground. CEO is verbally abusive, unqualified, unprofessional, and lacks any redeeming leadership skills outside of public speaking. She routinely bullies employees she doesn't like until they quit or get fired. HR has been virtually non-existent for years. Rare for reviews to happen on time if at all and when they do they are meaningless - top performers are lucky to get an inflation increase. General sentiment is that even the best employees are disposable, performance is subjective and hires/fires are spun however the CEO wants. C-Suite is disempowered and afraid of the CEO's unpredictable, nonsensical rants. Anyone logical who goes against the grain doesn't last long. Complete and utter disorganization from the top down. Impossible to get strategic, long-term work done because the staff is forced to operate like a bunch of firefighters, constantly dealing with daily emergencies as they come up. Demoralized staff at every level.

review_title: Terrible Culture - Divisive, Disorganized and Toxic
pros: Great mission - There are so many smart, passionate and hardworking employees.  I really enjoyed my time working with many of them.
cons:
I waited for at least a year to write this review because I'm  just getting over my dreadful experience.  
Accepting the role at Food Bank was the biggest professional mistake of my career. The leadership at this organization is disappointing to say the least. When I first started I was inspired by the mission and in awe of the leadership. Within months I realized something wasn’t right. The dysfunction, lack of communication and support is indescribable.  Staff are fearful of leadership and noone speaks up in fear of retaliation or termination.  The morale is incredibly low. There are so many smart and hardworking staff but so many of them are overworked and underappreciated and secretly unhappy .  I don’t recommend working here unless you want to be disrespected, alienated(if you have an opinion) and over-worked. 

If you’re into working for narcissists then this is the place for you.  That place is toxic and it's sad, I wish I never took the job. I write this review for ANYONE who is considering applying for a role at  Food Bank ...BEWARE.It’s a terrible place to work. If you have already accepted a role???….Godspeed (I hope you get a supportive and strong supervisor- there are a few there)

PS 
Don’t fall for these FB responses to the reviews. It’s another manipulation tactic and cover-up to lead you to believe this place is normal.  IT IS NOT NORMAL!

pros: The organization attracts a lot of great talent, but doesn’t do anything to encourage them to stay. What they say they do, they don’t deliver on. You’ll meet great people here, but prepare to say goodbye quickly. I made a list of 40+ people who have left in the two years I’ve been here. The organization is about 125 employees for reference.
cons:
Don’t listen to the website! Insurance isn’t 100% covered anymore, so I’ve LOST money by staying here. Also they don’t follow through on cost of living adjustments. They’ll say you earned one from your stellar review, but your paycheck shows they didn’t follow through. This happened to me TWICE. Maybe if they kept the one functional HR professional this would be better, but for now it’s an absolute mess. 

Also take a look at their tax form 990 on their website. It’s public knowledge senior leadership gets $40,000 bonuses when they won’t 
give their staff a living wage. $40,000 is more than what some staff make in a year, and now we have to pay for our own health insurance.

review_title: Where Passion For Mission Fuels Impact
pros: Food Bank For New York City's  organizational DNA is driven by a common sense of purpose and mission. That shared passion across the organization  drives impact at a citywide scale in the fight against hunger and poverty. Few organizations that I have been a part of have had the reach and results of Food Bank nor the collection of committed professionals spanning several different industries and areas of expertise, however united by a common purpose to make a difference in the lives of New Yorkers in need. Each and every day, I am proud to be a part of a team that is strengthening today's safety net, designing replicable and scalable anti-poverty solutions, and advocating for policies that together can bring us ever closer to ending hunger.
cons: In a fast-moving environment, organizational communication may not always keep pace. Food Bank is not immune to those challenges and I have seen the organization take steps to address this concern including strengthening new staff on-boarding and orientation as well as fostering greater cross-departmental coordination and communication.

review_title: Great organization with big culture problems
pros: A lot of great staff, the majority of whom are truly dedicated to the mission. The organization does really great work and there is opportunity to grow (in terms of experience, if you take initiative, though not necessarily in terms of position). Serving a network of food assistance, education and other organizations who do amazing work all around NYC. Great benefits as well.
cons: Most staff are quite overworked, and under appreciated by upper level staff. The top levels of staff  make a significant amount of decisions that are transparently ego-based and can be unresponsive and even derisive toward staff who are even just one level down. This leads to morale that is often very low, and high turnover.

pros: We work hard and make a difference. The CEO will put you on blast if you are putting our business at risk. She calls out donors and government that will not pay us and if another department is holding us back they get called out too at our staff meetings. It is honest and you know where you stand.The reviews on here are from people that do not like that. The people that leave the business think they are too smart to be here. I don’t even try and keep track of managers in the other offices because they leave so quick. There are other charities that they can work at so leave the jobs here for the workers.
cons: If you work at the kitchen you get free lunch and dinner. Bring that to everyone. We work all over the city so do not get to see each other except for parties.

pros: None, to be honest. The location downtown is cool, I guess.
cons: Everything - no one is happy at this office and no one trusts each other. Employees live in a constant state of fear that their co-workers are going to turn on them for something petty. They also use LOT of temps for cheap labor which doesn't help morale either, since people have to constantly re-train and then explain why people keep leaving. There are a ton of poor financial decisions being made - lots of cutting corners to save money, which makes you wonder, if it's this bad when the economy is great, how will it be once the market retreats? And then there's the turnover of senior staff. I think they've had...what...3 CFOs in as many years? Eek. And Directors that still remain are either always on the brink of "being fired" (as everyone will whisper)  or are trying to leave ASAP (which is really an open secret for, well, everyone). Can't wait to get out!

review_title: a fish stinks from the head down.
pros: The only pro is the organizations mission.
cons: The leadership. The CEO of this organization is ill-equipped to do her job and manages through hostility, fear-mongering, and verbal-abuse. The organization is broken and dysfunctional. Staff retention nonexistent, and those who do stay do as little as possible clocking out the second the clock hits 4:30pm because morale is so low. Nearly every senior level person to c-suite executive is looking for a new job. Rumor has it that HR posts "positive" reviews to this site to counter the harsh yet completely honest reviews that are posted here. The organization needs a complete overhaul.

review_title: A Fish "Always" Rots From The Head!
pros: Mission relevant to New Yorkers living at or below the poverty level.
cons: The CEO and C-Suite hide behind the Food Bank's mission and 30+ year legacy of service to fulfill their own selfish and greedy objectives. Check out the salary disparity between C-suite and everyone below the VP level. Frankly, no one is going to bite the hand that feeds them so no one will challenge the CEO or Chief of Staff / COO.  Sadly, the Board of Directors are willing to allow Food Bank's reputation and legacy suffer by choosing to not hold the CEO accountable for questionable decisions on the organization's financial management. One wonders about the reasons for the high turnover in the CFO role. I hope they have sufficient unrestricted funds in the coffers to routinely make payroll! Do yourself a favor: Work for and donate to City Harvest:  by far a better managed and more ethical organization serving New Yorkers.

review_title: The place to learn and lead...
pros: There are many opportunities to learn and lead within this organization. The generous benefits are but one of the many factors that make this organization great. There is a sincere connectedness to community and doing what's right for those we have the privilege to serve. Staff are smart and committed. Leadership is shared and expected within all levels of the organization. If you appreciate a challenge, are passionate about hunger and poverty issues and want to help solve these issues, this is an organization to be engaged with. It's certainly made a positive difference in my professional and personal life.
cons: need to build in more opportunities for reflection and team building

review_title: EGO feeding CEO and her bunch of "YES Ma'am!!" chiefs
pros: the mission, the day to day food bank employees who actually care for the organization and the clients FB serves
cons:
EGO feeding CEO and her bunch of "YES Ma'am " chiefs. Not to mention the incompetent Board of Directors who turns a blind eye to all the ego feeding, grossly ignorant and downright narcissistic decisions taken by the CEO. The sole purpose of the Board is JUST to make themselves feel good by being affiliated with a social services organization and/or something to talk about at a cocktail event!!

Human Resources is non-existent. HR's sole purpose is to pass confidential staff grievances and concerns to the CEO and her goonies. Also, to ILLEGALLY FORCE current employees into writing positive reviews on Glassdoor for the EGOCENTRIC CEO! SO PATHETIC :(

pros: Great mission and partners including Food Banks network and the general public. Lots of dedicated staff members who are committed to the mission despite very challenging circumstances.
cons: While the CEO is a great public speaker, there is a complete disconnect between the "talk" of the mission and the "walk" within the organization. The environment is abusive, dysfunctional and toxic, which is created from the top and works its way across and down the organization. The CEO frequently sends inappropriate, disparaging and abusive emails directed at staff members at all levels and mentioning members/organizations of the Food Bank network and external people. Forget work/life balance and count on zero professionalism. No sense of processes, planning, management or strategy. Everyone (including the senior executive team) walks on eggshells, no one is empowered and complete departments turn over on a near annual basis.

review_title: They tend to forget their staff are New Yorkers too
pros: The mission is awesome, we get to make a difference in the communities we live and work in.
cons: Employees are New Yorker's too, some of us are out fighting hunger all day and then go home to no food as well.

review_title: I am proud to serve the community, and feel great when I am able to help people.
pros: During the tax season, Food Bank For New York City offers free tax preparation program to low income people and to the elderly. I gained valuable experience during the time I worked at Food Bank For New York City. I had a chance to meet different people with different aspect of life. As a Tax Examiner and Tax Preparer, I always felt good every time I am able to help my clients claiming the maximum credits which entitlle to them using my tax laws knowledge.
cons: Only seasonal job!  I wish I can continue to work after the tax season because I love to work in the tax field!

review_title: Enjoyed my time at Food Bank
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The mission, the people and the generous donors and partnerships are what make Food Bank great! I had a lot of positive experiences at Food Bank. Leadership encourages employees to seize opportunities to improve and make things better. They also believe in promoting from within and creating opportunities for this to happen where possible.
cons: There is a lot of work and it's easy to get overwhelmed early on if there isn't a lot of direction and goals set for the employees.

pros: I came to Food Bank from a public-sector setting and to be honest, came in with some presuppositions about nonprofits that my experience here shows were not at all deserved. Food Bank is a well-run, high-functioning, high-impact nonprofit that values good management and develops staff talent.
cons: We are a mission-driven organization and team, and we drive ourselves really hard as a result -- burnout is something we always need to look out for. Our goals are always bigger than our resources.

pros: The staff, they are dedicated but are often demoralized.  Staff needs to be supported and paid fairly.
cons: Morale is very low and environment is tense to the point that some staff have gotten physically sick.

review_title: High energy place thats exciting right now
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Mission, leadership, benefits,  staff. We have a new president whos changing everything. People work now. It used to be a place where leaders were mean and full of themselves.  We talk about the mission and hungry people now.  Alot of the pompous VPs are gone and its so much better. We're happy now and get things done in a calm environment..
cons: Not alot of room for promotion. Hoping it will change too.

review_title: Reflecting on the years and Thanking You
pros:
As the holidays season is here and the year comes to an end I started to reflect on the years I've been a part of the Food Bank For NYC's family. As amazing as it is to serve the people of NYC it's just as amazing to be a part of such a wonderful family. It's such a great feeling to come to work and be around such a wonderful group of people. Besides the family atmosphere the things I'm most thankful for are  the opportunities giving to the staff. The promotions from within and  the hope that's gives to the young talented staff to ensure a real future.(EVERYONE MATTERS) As a new employee coming in you you're inspired because your supervisor/manager may have started out as a temp employee as well.                                                                                 (HOPE AND INSPIRATION  IS SUCH A WONDERRFUL THING)
 I also love, witnessed and been a part of C suites/senior leadership/management and staff being  there for  employees and their families in time of need. The CEO, COO and VP in attendance at employees families funerals. ( THAT DOES'NT HAPPEN EVERYWHERE)  
With that being said I just want to say Thank You Food Bank For NYC for not just being there for NYC, but for me, my family at home and MY FOOD BANK FOR NYC FAMILY!!!!!
cons: WISH MORE PEOPLE WOULD GET INVOLVED TO HELP US IN OUR MISSION

pros: The mission is phenomenal, and I'm pretty sure the impact numbers Food Bank boasts are real. Many staff members genuinely care about the organization and go above and beyond.
cons: There are so many internal problems that I find it hard to be concise, but the bottom line? This organization is broken. I left after only a year because it is so very, very broken. I believe Food Bank is being run into the ground by the CEO, who (despite her terrific public speaking skills) is a terrible manager of people. In my heart of hearts I think she truly believes she is doing the right thing, which makes it all the more heartbreaking. I believed in her at the beginning. I was charmed by her passion and energy. I was inspired by the way she can wax poetic about how Food Bank is uniquely positioned to help solve the broad and complex problems of hunger and poverty in NYC. She had me fooled for a while, but it didn't take long for me to see her true colors. During my time at Food Bank, she routinely spoke badly about her employees and sent verbally abusive mass e-mails to entire departments, offering an abundance of complaints and threats but nothing in the way of constructive criticism. She created and fostered a culture of fear, which was funneled down to every department through the C-suite executives who walked on egg-shells at all times. High level employees (i.e. C-Suite, directors, and upper management) dropped like flies while I was there - you would see them one day, and literally the next day they would be gone with zero explanation about the reason for their departure. Speculation ran wild about whether they were fired by the CEO, quit from being bullied by her, or simply left in exasperation. When these employees mysteriously disappeared, no exit strategy was created by remaining staff, and lower level employees would routinely be found floundering under piles of new responsibilities they were often ill equipped to handle. Employee morale was low, and turn over continues to be high. I voluntarily left about a year ago, and there are very few of my former colleagues who remain. It truly breaks my heart. I wanted to love Food Bank. I wanted to stay for years and years because I believe in the mission of the organization. Unfortunately, the toxicity of the CEO ultimately sent me running. I actually overheard her telling her C-Suite executives that she wasn't the reason turn over was so high, but they were. I'm sorry, but I beg to differ.

review_title: An incredibly hostile place to work, on earth!
pros: A  worthy legacy thanks to Dr. Cabrera (former CEO)! Unfortunately, current leadership has been unable to sustain an environment of integrity.
cons: C-suite lacks management expertise and business acumen and they know it! The inability to hire and retain competent leaders in Finance, Marketing, Programs and Operations. Unfortunately, if "you're not with them, you're against them which means...you're out"!  Don't hesitate, work at, or donate to "City Harvest"!

pros: When I worked here the best reason was the work, then it was the great benefits (free health care, 10% salary match with no contribution). At the end of 2012-13 the best thing my time here taught me was how not to act, how not to lead and how not to run an organization.
cons: At the end of 2012-13 not much was good. And from my conversations with those that stayed, the organization has nothing to do with making an impact and only about the distructive CEO and her nepotism.

pros: The mission is exemplar and the organization has done great things for New Yorkers.
cons: President has serious emotional problems.  She is a great public speaker, but a mean-spirited and absent leader.  She refuses to engage on projects, gives little direction, and then at the end she nixes what her staff members have done.  There's an amazing amount to wasted effort.  She is a self-esteem vampire and gets pleasure in hurting people. She has caused many great employees to leave, fires without cause, and has been responsible for funders to take their support to other organizations.

pros: Organization has a terrific mission and a well thought out strategy. Rewarding work, excellent work/life balance. Great lay for a non profit and excellent benefits.
cons: Emergency feeding is not for the weak. Your hand will not be held and you are expected to perform at a very high level ALL THE TIME.

pros: Great Mission and Reach, many talented people on staff
cons: Overpaid Chiefs and other executive level.  Allows programs and other mission based initiatives to suffer while execs make huge salaries

job_title: Just There in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, some really nice people, caring workers.
cons: Non friendly, egotistical management staff, rude and condescending feedback from managers, directors, management can never do wrong but quick to point out others mistakes.

cons: President and upper management don't know how to run a not-for-profit organization. Decisions made to feed egos, not to carry out the real work. Since new president and senior staff started employees are treated really badly.

pros: great friendly people that are on a mission to help the community.
cons: they are not always organized , when you need to talk to a manager they take forever to respond

pros: Good morale at headquarters and pretty even-headed management. The staff are cheery and courteous most days, even when busy.
cons: Turnover means a lot of institutional knowledge can be easily lost. Not so unusual for not-for-profits, but it can do something to the learning curve.

good for resume building if you are a student

non-profit, help people in needed

people came and left quick, most of them are interns
low pay and need to work at other job at same time

pros: I was able to pack food for families in need. I was packing with others, so there was a great emphasis on teamwork to increase efficiency.

Great mission... helping to end hunger in NYC.

pros: Helping people is very nice.

pros: Passionate employees, ready to make you feel comfortable and get started

review_title: Avoid this organization at all costs
